My border-country friend asserted that Monopoly is more fun if you can steal from the bank whilst the other player isn’t looking. (I still won.) Later, we ate my homemade Christmas pudding, and drank 25-year-old Laphroaig neat from the bottle. Thorn, his gentle black Labrador, eagerly cleaned our plates of leftovers.<br/> <br/> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/folkjokeopus/5292262309/" title="Using a friend's camera - by Folkjokeopus, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5129/5292262309_1698867d7b.jpg" width="500" height="357" alt="" /></a><br/> <br/> On the 24th we’d taken a slow walk by the forest and rivers which form at the rear of his house. Excluding garden and orchard, he owns about 15 acres of woodland in total (the rest is publicly accessible). He lent me use of one of his (entry-level) cameras in the absence of my own, but I was too shutter shy and only took ten photos, almost all of which I deleted after seeing his efforts.<br/> <br/> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/folkjokeopus/5292261775/" title="Taken by my friend - by Folkjokeopus, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5162/5292261775_696ddf247b.jpg" width="500" height="357" alt="" /></a><br/> <br/> There is mistletoe growing parasitically on one of his older apple trees. After dessert, he went outside to pick some and came back half an hour later, emblazoned from head to waist in their slender stems and translucent white berries, like a festive version of the Green Man. <br/> <br/> Apart from laughing, the other activity his endearing daftness so easily mustered from me was, of course, a traditional mistletoe kiss. I’ve succeeded by miraculously acquiring ‘flu three out of the last four years.<br/> <br/> I think about my estranged father a lot around this time. Despite his atrocities, I still try to wish him well. A small part of me is unsure if he is even lucid enough any more to distinguish one day from another, but perhaps his empty mind is for the best.<br/> <br/> *<br/> <br/> Since the 14th, I’ve been with my border-country friend. It was a last-minute decision to travel up to him, but a good one, nonetheless.<br/> <br/> <img src="http://i295.photobucket.com/albums/mm138/dwillandbiscuit/puddingsmall.jpg"><br/> <br/> I made a traditional Christmas pudding the day before I left. It was supposed to journey with me to my family in London, but that fell through. Now it will help sustain my too-thin companion as he <i>again</i> graciously allows me to crash with him over this holiday season. It frustrates me that he is happy to accept a pudding in lieu of actual payment. (Last time was a <a href="http://folkjokeopus.codexed.com/2010/10/25/home-away-from-home">cinnamon-apple cake</a>, amongst other things.)<br/> <br/> <img src="http://i295.photobucket.com/albums/mm138/dwillandbiscuit/pudding2.jpg"><br/> <br/> If I had more time (and had uploaded all the images before leaving Devon), there would have been a recipe to accompany this. (It’s delicious.) Never mind.<br/> <br/> *<br/> <br/> The weather in this part of the country can be brutal and unforgiving at the best of times. Those who live on the most isolated northerly extremities or archipelagos have almost no means of accessing basic amenities when the snow is this treacherous. My friend has been unable to work (outside) for the last two weeks, but at least he’s only an hour’s (cautious) drive from town. It’s more than most.<br/> <br/> Except for a few times on skis, I’ve never experienced this amount of snow before; sadly, I don’t have my camera here to record it. In some places, the drifts reach our knees, so we pull on waist-high waders when (nervously) out walking. Even so, I’ve lost count of the number of icicles I’ve crunched, and the lacy snowflakes that have melted on my tongue.<br/> <br/> *<br/> <br/> The last couple of days have been the most hurtful in just as many years. Despite feeling (cognitively) worse than when I left last week, I’m trying my hardest to remain upbeat, at least for the benefit of others. The brown trout will be slow and dumb in this cold spell, they said. For trespassers on private land, they were surprisingly vocal.<br/> <br/> They were guided by the light of their mobile phones, and their long rods were held aloft, like masts, as they slowly picked their way towards the lake. They set down their bait boxes and cast two lines. I watched them from the barn.<br/> <br/> I gave them ten minutes, I think. Enough to get comfortable in the reeds, and familiar with the tension of their reels. <br/> <br/> When the halogen lamp snapped on, it illuminated the whole lake like the sky had lit a flare, and the old boughs of the oak tree burned shadows on the lawn. The night fishers panicked and bolted across the tall grass, through a hole in the hedgerow. In the sudden light they were nothing more than two slight teenagers in black cagoules. <br/> <br/> I couldn’t sleep after that, and went indoors, somewhat shaken. It’s getting too cold in the barn for a two-season sleeping bag, anyway.<br/> <br/> *<br/> <br/> This morning began bright and burnished. I’m writing this on a bus, which has just crossed the border out of Devon. It perturbs me just how appalling my writing was prior to my return here, and I wonder how long these words will remain visible before I balk and remove them again. (Incidentally, I recently unearthed a surfeit of journal entries from 2003 to 2004, and they’re so mortifyingly overdramatic, I couldn’t bear to read them all through.)<br/> <br/> *<br/> <br/> The conservation qualification has been shifted forward again, to the first week in January. This is favourable because it leaves me with less idle time to squander, but I cannot shake the (as yet unfounded) trepidation that I will neither be suitable, nor capable, of this type of physical labour. My body is lithe and wiry, but I still don’t know if I’ll be able to carry heavy stones, or how difficult the various tools will be to operate. I’m used to achieving, and have never really been in a position where it’s likely I’ll be (literally) the weakest link.<br/> <br/> Invasive (plant) species control is a skill I have an elementary understanding of, but for the most part, I’ll be plunged into the deep end. My biggest concern is being unable to master the building of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dry_stone#Dry_stone_walls">dry-stone walls</a>, a tradition I’ve been enamoured with for several years (thanks to the work of Andy Goldsworthy), and more so since moving to the countryside and having the privilege of seeing such accomplished masonry in situ. And, up until last week, I didn’t even own the right clothing (steel-toe boots, drill trousers, padded shirts), none of which do women’s sizes. <br/> <br/> I understand that everyone has to start somewhere, and I’m not irked by beginning at the bottom. After my shift, I jogged back through the forest, and had just enough time to pack a rucksack and make the impromptu journey east to my old home.<br/> <br/> We drank gin in the mosh pit, and struggled to breathe beneath the hot cloud of taller followers. I still knew all the words, still remembered to sneer and swagger to the choruses. Most of the gigs I attend take place in a village hall, or in someone’s cosy front room. This arena seemed like an entirely different planet, populated by whirring beams, and shape-throwing, and lighter flames floating dreamily above my head.<br/> <br/> *<br/> <br/> I’m no stranger to sleeping rough. When my depression was at its worst, I used to travel several hundred miles north to Yorkshire and take cover for a night (or more) against the leeward side of a hedgerow or dry-stone wall. The cold (and the absolute feeling of isolation) lulled me to sleep after long days of wandering the moors. Admittedly, this was several years ago, and now I’d at least have the good sense to bring a tent should this desire rear again.<br/> <br/> Having spent the last three weeks <a href="http://folkjokeopus.codexed.com/2010/11/18/sunset-over-the-lake">bedded in the barn</a>, curling up on a station bench in early December was a fairly simple decision to make. I could have turned up at my mother’s house in the suburbs, but I knew she had several guests over. (Of course) she wouldn’t have sent me away, but I didn’t want the company. The claustrophobia of the concert was enough, as was the clutter of my mind.<br/> <br/> If I’d shared the station with another sleeper, a homeless person, perhaps, then I might have felt more guilty over my selective recklessness, and booked accommodation or crashed with one of my friends, instead. A few winters ago I volunteered at a soup-run, and it was by far one of the most harrowing (and humbling) three months of my life. My living arrangements in Devon may currently be uncertain, but there’s no doubting that I’m incredibly fortunate in (almost) every aspect of my existence.<br/> <br/> The next morning, I walked diagonally from one corner of London to the other. It took me the whole day, including passing through the centre of the shopping district (I didn’t buy any presents), before finally catching the train home. Through the plate windows, it happened to be the first clear night since November. There were three shooting stars within the space of a couple of minutes. We work from five a.m. to eleven a.m. (I only attend three times a week), with a thirty minute break. <br/> <br/> If the task requires a group effort, such as ‘steeping’ (<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedge_laying">hedge laying</a>), we vote on when to take the break; if we’re working individually (planting a row of saplings, say), it’s up to us. The general consensus is that the later the break is taken, the less time there is left to labour before one can go home.<br/> <br/> On Saturday’s break, I was collared by one of the older volunteers (he is thirty-seven). We talked about what we’d done prior to joining this team. He told me he left school at sixteen and has worked on the land ever since. He said he was volunteering here because he wanted to move from farming to forestry. Finally, he asked, bluntly, why someone like me wanted to work in such a physical, male-dominated environment (<i>with your posh accent and your degrees</i>, were his precise words).<br/> <br/> After explaining my reasons, I (cynically) assumed he would reproach me for shunning the opportunities offered to me in academia, but instead he told me I was making a courageous decision; he thought it admirable that I wanted to make a quiet(er) impact on the world, one that was <i>expressed in leaves, not lectures</i>. It was his last day volunteering before he travelled back home (towards the north). I never learned his name, but his statement stuck with me. He reminded me of my border-country friend, whom I’m missing terribly.<br/> <br/> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/48654471@N03/5222279146/" title="Untitled by Folkjokeopus, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5163/5222279146_0a3766745d.jpg" width="500" height="281" alt="" /></a><br/> <br/> Where I work is an hour away from my home. London shapes and reshapes overnight, Devon remains static. The thatched roofs might moss over a little more, the bracken might encroach on the footpath, but except for the gentle intrusion of the four seasons, home looks like home, month on end. I find this familiarity comforting, especially since I’ve been so reluctant to return. <br/> <br/> To counteract some of the difficulties I’m facing now I’m finally back, I’ve re-launched myself into volunteering. The lackadaisical approach they have to hours means I can come and go as I please. At six o’clock this morning, I helped fell an infested elm. Dutch Elm disease is one of the most prolific and destructive arboreal afflictions. It upset me to witness it, but for the sake of the surrounding woodland ecology, it was terribly necessary to do.<br/> <br/> I’ve also been accepted to work towards a skills-based qualification in conservation. There’ll be some written exams, which, even with my embarrassingly modest knowledge, I hope to breeze through, but mostly I’ll be learning how to ‘gap’ (repair) and build dry-stone walls, work with soil and trees, etc. It will be physically demanding, but (save for my problematic knee) I’m lucky to be fit and active.<br/> <br/> Somewhat concomitantly, a friendly local restaurant in my town has asked me to adorn their walls with moorland photographs. In return, I get all the profits made on any that sell. Once I buy a new backpack, I’ll be spending even more time outside, simply looking for the loveliest compositions. Just my camera and I. His phone is never switched on, so perhaps I should have called a ranger, but instead I just sat numbly in the study, worrying and waiting for him. When the sun eventually rolled through the wet fog, I offered to walk his dog, a black Labrador Retriever, because I knew he wouldn’t find the time.<br/> <br/> Thorn and I covered about five miles in total, passing leisurely from one village to another via the forest track. I decided to take a running kick for the ball, but my right knee slipped in its joint, and I collapsed.<br/> <br/> (Some of you who have read me from the beginning may remember an operation I underwent last year for <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osteochondritis_dissecans">Osteochondritis Dissecans</a>, which stemmed from a hockey match injury at the age of sixteen. My weakened right knee will only ever have about 75% functionality on a good day, and I can’t kneel on it, nor run at any speed. This news was hard to take for a teenager who once had the potential to compete as a cross-country athlete.)<br/> <br/> My instinctive reaction was to stand up again, but I couldn’t. There was a worryingly familiar clunking feeling beneath the patella. A lady walked past with a Highland Terrier, and Thorn (who had sat protectively beside me as I winced) rushed to greet it.<br/> <br/> ‘Get your fucking dog away from my dog,’ she (unnecessarily) retorted. I tried to call Thorn over, but he (as dogs are wont to do) put blinkers on and continued playfully gambolling with the terrier. It was clear that I was injured, but she proceeded to curse aggressively. Eventually I managed to raise myself and grasp Thorn’s collar, but not before being told that I was a ‘thoroughly incompetent owner.’<br/> <br/> Upset, I called my friend, who drove over immediately and lifted me into the car. Back home, he carried me up the stairs and helped me limp out of my muddy clothes, into pyjamas. He wrapped my knee in a cold compress and brewed Earl Grey tea. Work was postponed for the rest of the evening.<br/> <br/> Despite my friend’s quiet (but genuine) insistence that he wasn’t irritated, I have never felt so guilty for disturbing someone before, nor have I ever been made to feel so unjustly inadequate by a complete stranger.<br/> <br/> This morning, my knee feels better. It’s red and swollen, but the joint isn’t rubbing anymore and I can walk without howling.
